messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: tumb@... [mailto:tumb@...]
>
> Is there any recommended (or better yet documented) ideal level of
> testing?

J.B. Rainsberger has a nice phrase to answer this: "Test until fear turns to
boredom." That's one way to think about it.

There are so many types of testing, there is no one ideal level. I mean
there's unit testing, subsystem testing, integration testing, various types
of load testing (performance, stress, reliability, scalability), install and
configuration testing, etc.

There are a few metrics that can be a good guide though.

1. Code coverage analysis. Everyone will say 100% code coverage is ideal.
They won't always say 100% what -- line, method, branch, path? But in my
experience 100% coverage of any kind never gets done in reality (maybe the
next product I work on!). 70% statement coverage is very good for a new
server-side software product of 200K lines of code, in my experience. Maybe
it's easier for GUI programs.

2. McCabe's metric (aka, cyclomatic complexity -- based on the number of
branches possible in a method). This metric along with lines of code
metrics, actually, can be a guide to how many bugs you should find in a
piece of code (more if it's new code, less if it's tried and true, reused
code). But it's just a heuristic. Can't be relied on for more than a guide
for where you should focus your tests.

3. Bug metrics. If you track bugs and you can get reports from the bug
tracker somehow, look at bug entry and fix trends. Bug finding, represented
by new bugs entered, should slow down prior to shipping the product. If
there's no sign of slowing, and QA is finding good bugs, then you obviously
can't have much confidence in the quality of the software. The rate of bug
fixing should also slow down and stabilize prior to shipping, because
roughly 1 out of 4 bug fixes introduces a regression or a new bug. So QA
needs time to re-test software after it's been fixed.

> Our company is working on adopting XP and perhaps test driven practises.
> We have a question about whether certain groups are testing too little or
> too much. How, if at all, do you determine what's too little or too much?

You should really check out the testdrivendevelopment@yahoogroups.com group.
There's a currently a discussion about how TDD is more about design than
testing.

Scott Stirling
